div1.p: [Carter] discusses her concerns about unfinished maps for the completed manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, April 5, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Misel.
Russell (Report-weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
April 5, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Miss Brown and I are still putting in long hours on the “dimin-
ishing” bibliographic “returns” while I await Dr. Frost's summons to
Baltimore. In the course of a telephone conversation with Mrs. Frost
last Monday, she told me that Dr. Frost was in New York that day, but
that he hoped, “very shortly” to be able to resume the work on the final
editing of Father's MS.

In addition to the contemplated bibliographic work with Dr.
Frost, I am extremely anxious to discuss with him the selection of the
men to be asked to fill in the our outline maps, which have been ready
and waiting this long time. I took the data on this subject over to
the Dr. Frost last December, but he had only time to spare for the more
pressing work on the bibliographic files before leaving Baltimore on
“flu” work. He told me, however, that he felt that the matter should
be gone over carefully before we decided which particular men should
be approached re the filling in of these maps--I say “men” as we shall
probably have to have some of the maps filled in by different authorities
familiar with the respective eras they are to represent. As soon there-
fore as Dr. Frost can go into this matter with, I shall take it up with the
men we decide on, in order to have all such material ready by the time
the MS is in shape for you.

Miss Brown will continue her volunteer services as long as there
is anything left which she can do to help us. I have been to the Library
of Congress to check up some of her findings this week--excellent work!
I wish I could have had time to write (or you to read!) a more detailed
account of the past year's work on the verification of our bibliography.
bibliography.
-2-

It hasn't seemed worth while to stress the difficulties, but--
Sherlock Holmes' clues were a “broad highway” to some of the faint,
elusive and tortuous “trails” which we have followed--and followed
to their source! We could never have covered the ground had we
worked “Union hours,” at which rate it would have taken about two
years. This, of course, on account of the imperfect data we had to
go on and the mass of material to be covered in consequence. For
instance, my Aunt, in looking at a packed file case of 4″×6″ bibliogra-
phic cards, remarked: “I suppose that sometimes one of those little
things represents as much as three or four hours work?” She happened,
as she spoke, to have picked out one of our pet abominations--and
final triumphs--which, I was able to assure her, represented eight
days work, on the part of Miss Brown and a couple of hours of checking
thereafter of my own!

Of course, as I wrote you long since, the quotations essential
to the epidemiological argument of Father's MS were concentrated upon
and verified last year but, since I have this unexpected hiatus to
fill in it is a great satisfaction to get as good results from it as
we are getting.

With best wishes and trusting that when next I write it will be
to give you news of work in Baltimore,
div1.closer:
Very truly yours,
Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
